oQKWvtUB-0Em77X4k8KFmg.text: My first visit to Koya (the restaurant) was admittedly underwhelming. I guess I didn't know what I was really expecting from the place. But I've been back several times since and I've been cautious about writing a review because I find myself liking it more and more everytime. Until now, I think I actually crave a bit of Koya every now and then. The udon is great, but that on its own would never have earned a 5-star rating, there's so much more to Koya. Let's start with udon - hand made, the udon at Koya has a great texture, I always get the udon cold because I like the tenacity and would prefer that they were kept that way until I decide to eat it. The broths and choices are simple and straight forward. I didn't quite get the flavours at first, but the more I eat here, the more I appreciate the simplicity. The walnut paste and mushrooms is definitely one of my favourite here, but everything's good. What tips Koya off the scale and into 5 star territory is / are its specials. They change with frequency and it always brings something new to the table. They marry ingredients I would never have dreamt of, and honestly opens my taste palette to new experiences. How could I not give them 5 stars. The last special I had was the John Dory sashimi with soy marinated cucumbers and something really fragrant on the plate. The flavours were gentle and worked in harmony. It delighted and suprised me. As for it's pork belly - I always get this - it's just divine.

_dZEryHCBXY446sqOasI-w.text: The menu's not extensive, but if you know what you want and they have what you want, then Koya Bar is the place to go. There's often a queue in the evening, but not as long as Koya's.Tip: If you get the cold udon and hot brother, you start eating it relatively quickly. I lingered with my starter for too long, and then I had cold udon and warmish broth, which got cold pretty quickly when I added the noodles.I also really like their tempura, though an entire portion plus udon is a little much, so try to get someone to share. My favourites are the spring onion and tofu cold udon, for a hot summer day, the mushroom and walnut miso udon, and the ten curry don. £2 is excessive for an extra poached egg... but I get it anyway.I haven't been to Koya yet, so can't compare.

95qfPtKuumrK6MX1tLGT3Q.text: Ordinary food, rude service. I put my opened pudding on the table. A waitress came twice about it( How can I put an opened food back to my bag excuse me?). The second time she said: I don't want to see it on the table！EXCUSE ME? She was literally so rude. BTW, she has a short hair Asian face.

v-qi2blSkqqIMxollthJtw.text: The little sibling of the larger Koya restaurant next door, Koya Bar is styled after the traditional Ramen houses where customers sit along a bar facing the kitchen. The menu here is more limited than its neighbour but the dishes are freshly made in front of you which provides a great opportunity to watch the chefs at work and see each step as your dish is assembled. The atmosphere is Spartan and the layout is challenging to socialise in groups, so Koya Bar is best suited for a quick catch up with a friend or a bowl of noodles before heading out in the area. Prices are reasonable with main dishes around the £10 mark.The Kedgeree was fairly authentic and may be a good entry dish if you find yourself a bit dubious about the whole thing. The rice porridge is grainer than your standard cooked oats and the smoked haddock gives the dish a light savoury flavour. It's a step above congee (although I've had some full-bodied congee in my time) and is filling and warming - great if you are feeling the chill or are a bit under the weather.My curry udon noodles were fine but lacking the hefty punch I associate with curry. This is undoubtedly a result of my tendency to eat my mom's spicy chicken curries for breakfast whenever I'm at my parents' house so I imagine it's more than sufficient for the average person - particularly for breakfast!Rob H, Katie B's partner in crime, raves about the English Breakfast udon which is your standard udon noodle soup topped with a fried egg, bacon, and shiitake mushrooms. While it did look pretty good (and who doesn't love the smell of sizzling bacon), it's a hybrid dish I still can't quite get on board with. That being said, he's a noodle aficionado so there must be something to it.For a tenner, you do get a decent serving of food and service is fast and efficient if not the most friendly. I'm more than happy to drop in to line the stomach but if I had more time to kill (or was with more than one person) I think Bone Daddies has them beat.

jzKFXJC9frh-ibHUNtcfnw.text: My second time at Koya Bar and both times I've thoroughly enjoyed my food! Staff are polite, helpful and very knowledgable about the dishes. The food they serve is so fresh and full of quality. I will be back!

ILaStRKD2BsW0f1ihLz7mw.text: After the very, very sad closure of the original Koya restaurant, this is now my favourite spot for Udon in London. The udon is as great as it was next door, and the bar layout usually means shorter waiting times, although it is better suited for two or three than for a larger group (there are no tables, everyone sits around the bar). Order a starter from their specials menu - they make fantastic little plates, such as pickled cucumber or various salads etc. Really great stuff..

-Qaq27AKt5jLApKIsgkUgA.text: Koya might be the best Japanese food I've had outside of Japan. Everything had that quality, fresh, deceptively simple flavor palate that's actually anything but. Usually I find that when a traditional style place tries to do something a bit outside the main cuisine or get fusion-y it doesn't go well, but as a testament to the chef's mastery even the lettuce wrap special we tried was fantastic and fit right in with the rest of the menu. It took me right back to the year I spent in Tokyo. If you're a tourist like I was in London, you might not think to hit up a Japanese noodle bar during your trip, but I promise you won't be disappointed.

JTikuYsER9GhlXXqnUKCTg.text: Awesome noodles for an affordable price. Be prepared for a long queue but it will be worthwhile.

f2ohZw7XgV01aOcWVPm6ZA.text: Yummy yummy noodles! The udon is so chewy and fresh. The side dishes are very nice too, and the tempura is some of the best I've had, all freshly cooked in front of you. Loved the tofu side dish too.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly with mustard
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Udon with tofu
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Tofu

ejuWWw1NWHp7QJryrArcmw.text: Rather flavourless udon noodles. Poor quality packet-miso. I wouldn't recommend Koya.

I14TkB-UEDA3L8gDbcdTXw.text: Thanks to Katie B for organising UYE breakfast edition here!  I've never had Japanese breakfast before, so I was keen on trying it out. I went with the Kedgeree (£10), which is a rice porridge with smoked haddock, poached egg, and curry.  I enjoyed the dish, the smoked haddock was lovely, and it even came with a little dish of toasted anchovy flakes (could be something else, but its extremely fragrant and not fishy!) to sprinkle on top.  I could eat the powder on its own! I felt the Kedgeree was the most interesting main dish, as the other ones were pretty standard with eggs and bacon, with the occasional shiitake thrown in there.  Overall, it was a good and light (ie: non greasy) breakfast to start the day.While it was delicious, I thought the price was a bit steep (£15 including service and tea), but quality Japanese food will be on the pricier side in this city.   On the upside, the staff were really nice, and it was incredibly clean (a big plus in my books!)However - I AM keen on coming back to Koya bar to try their non breakfast items!

HIK6NJw4lkLfD89w-uHB_A.text: Same concept as Koya next door, udon, udon, udon.  Pork belly udon was our favorite, with pork fat galore and the most flavorful broth of the three we ordered. Duck udon was our next favorite, especially with its tender meat.  The shrimp tempura needed to be eaten quickly otherwise it gets a big soggy.Squash and sesame, agedashi tofu were perfect starters to the meal, small enough to whet our appetites,  big enough to share.  The wait was about 30 minutes at 7:00, but it seemed the turnover was fast.  I think if you have a larger group, Koya is the way to go.  But if you're looking for a quick udon fix sitting at the bar, Koya Bar is sufficient.

EGnAP9uoiXzB6eT4jFMnAA.text: Transport yourself to Tokyo and sample the amazing clean flavours of Japan. Perch yourself on bar stools and slurp down some smooth chewy udon noodles. Not a place to hang around especially with a wriggly baby in your lap (no high chairs available) londonfoodiemama.tumblr.…

mcLfZuQqTI3Q7pe2oE9rnQ.text: Perfect for a quick solo lunch on a cold day - excellent noodle soups and daily specials. Not a lot of veg options, and menu is small yet tasty. I'd go with one other person max. Great for walk-ins.

ApwjKf4r58JhjHMP0cjXew.text: I love this place, I've been probably 50 times over the past three years. The staff are really pleasant, and the food clean, fresh, interesting, inventive, frequently rotates, with some of the special udon dishes like the sake steamed clam udon the best food I have eaten. The atmosphere is great too. The revelation, apart from the special udon, is the breakfasts, especially for me the japanese-style kedgeree. Long love Koya bar.

ZlLAgU4gPdoVzEiz8qT1DQ.text: The udon soups are delish. The sashimi and mushroom starters that I ordered are also really yummy. Vegetable tempura nicely battered and fried.

yemt5CQ3fuiFSRq9hYH6SQ.text: I've been to both Koya Frith St locations a few times in the past few years. I was anticipating a tasty buta miso (pork broth) udon. In the past it's been mouth wateringly good, worth lining up for. Yesterday I arrived at 5pm for an early dinner, no line up for the first time ever. Seated straight away. Service was friendly as usual, and our order was received pretty quickly.To my disappointment, the portion of tasty pork has been HALVED and the broth while good wasn't as tasty as I remember. On a good day £9.90 is pushing it for a bowl of udon, but the tastiness used to be worth it.With such a meanly small portion of pork mince, it definitely wasn't worth it this time. Why does everything that is good get changed?Koya has ticked me off and I'm now looking for my next udon place.

vMW4hdw4EAdzyiecU7tpgA.text: This is nirvana for noodle lovers. If you are like me and secretly want to quit school/work and run away to operate a noodle cart in Japan, this is a heaven sent. Seating is cramped as it is a bar, but this makes for an amazing atmosphere. The chefs operate behind the bar, so you get to watch their traditional udon-making process, which is a treat. The noodles are amazing and served in 4 different ways- cold with dipping sauce, cold with pouring sauce, hot in hot broth, and cold in hot broth. They're all good options, but I find the last one needs some explanation: it is a plate of cold udon noodles that you add on your own to the hot broth. The broths and sauces are yummy- I recommend the smoked mackerel. This is not your pho soup or Chinese noodle shop. Udon is different and will taste much better if you go in without these expectations. Give it a try for the experience, or become a regular because of your noodle obsession. Either way, Koya is worth a visit.

ci1MUWRy5N2bebeQME_r_A.text: The restaurant provide traditional Japanese food.  but the fish is too salty

-5ds2ZKSKnJJ4yxkNqocQA.text: I really dug this place, so much so I ate here twice in two separate trips to London.  This place has a nice compact menu, with couple of every variety, I had a cold udon with hot soup my first time along with some pork belly and I was blown away.  The noodles snapped, they were just chewy enough, the soup had enough flavor but was not over powering.  The pork belly was flavorful, moist, fall apart tender, yummmm.The second time I had a hot udon and was not disappointed either, everything is cooked right in front of you in a very precise manner.  Dinner time always has a line so try it later or earlier in the evening.

7eN-wFhjiefscH84jTm3-w.text: There is a beautiful thing about a bowl of soup noodles, and Koya is in the pursuit of perfecting it. Upon entering, the minimalistic yet elegant bar is lined with stools, where one can view into the kitchen and noodle-preparing process.  At noon on a Tuesday, there were a few customers, but it was kind of serenely quiet.I ordered the plain udon (kake) for £6.90.  The broth was the best I had ever had: light, flavorful, a heady fragrance, simple yet complex without being overly-salty. It was beautiful; I could have just had a bowl of broth and been satisfied.  The bowl came with a generous helping of udon and a sprinkle of spring onions. I prefer chewier udon, so I think my noodles were cooked for a bit too long. Overall, though, a great experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Plain udon (kake) 6.90

orcdX7eBgBxWXTaKzbdU1g.text: Sometimes, I think my stomach is leading me! I was in the mood for udon after an evening out with a friend at London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. I arrived on Frith street to find the usual long queue waiting to get into KoyaMy tummy rumbled sadly. I looked up, thinking of alternative noodley places when I saw a group of happy people slurpling noodles from a bowl through the window of the shop next door. Huh, what's this place, I thought to myself.Koya Bar!! My favourite place to sit in Koya is at the kichen counter to watch the chefs at work. Now, they've created a restaurant where there is only kitchen counter seatingThe menu is virtually identical to Koya next door. I had my usual atsu atsu (hot udon noodles with hot broth) with tempura prawn. I also had one of their specials on the board - squid, watercress with sansho miso - nicely sauteed squid with slightly peppery watercress and sweet glazeThe bonus of Koya Bar is that there was no wait while there was long queue for Koya. Bonus!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Tempura prawn udon
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Squid & watercress in sansho miso
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

LUnBlhoSLfe6cZYvNtBqEA.text: The eating scene in London is truly amazing. There are so many options, regardless of time or day of the week. After seeing Matilda The Musical at Cambridge Theatre, we went to Koya Bar in Soho for some dinner. Seeing as half of our party was meat eaters and the the other half vegetarian/pescetarian, Koya Bar was the perfect fit as they offer a variety of options. Koya Bar is, like with many other London eateries, on the smaller scale, with an open kitchen and a bar surrounding it. Luckily, the seven of us managed to get a seat before the dinner rush.Aside from offering various udon dishes, Koya Bar also has donburi (a bowl of rice topped with something) and side items like tempura, pork belly and vegetables. Next time I'm in London, I'll definitely make a trip to Koya Bar again! From our experience it's best to get there around six-ish or even earlier, as the place fills up quickly and there's always a queue, even on a week day! And they don't take reservations. The people who work there are friendly and you can tell, dedicated and passionate about udon and good Japanese food.

EfBFY3yDDNUH_zWtPGrwVg.text: I really love the idea of getting the food cooked right in front of myself, which is absolutely the case at Koya. Overall, it has a very nice "minuscule bar in Tokyo" feel, which I liked - it could draw attention to itself a bit better, though (maybe a bigger sign?).The cooks are at the same time the servers and friendly.The food was on top, as well. I also ordered green tea, which came in a lovely little ceramic pot. Despite the fact that the place was absolutely packed even at 10pm, it didn't take too long until I found myself enjoying some amazing udon.Absolutely do come early, though, as the bar can accommodate perhaps 15-20 people, consequently bringing a group of friends might be a problem.The toilets are nice and tidy, and - like the rest of the bar - tastefully decorated in a modern Japanese style.I know where I'll be eating at my next visit to London.

8P4rxDEbd_XiKxx5oZW_lg.text: There is always a queue at this place and I hate waiting for food, no matter how good so I decided to come back at an odd hour by myself (Saturday afternoon, around 2pm) when the queue was less than 20 minutes long and inside the door. The 25 seater bar had a very cozy feel and everybody was seated rapidly - the star of the restaurant is udon and the pork miso one I had was very delicious - just the right size for me - I wish that they had served the egg with the udon rather than first as I think the two would have gone together. Next time will order more small plates to share and maybe bring one addidtional person tops.

q7v9dIeUvvVZM5F6tUreYA.text: Looking for some delicious udon but want to avoid the long lines at Koya? Koya Bar is the answer!!We were waiting in line for Koya when the hostess said we could try Koya Bar next door with no wait ....so of course we did! They told us the menus are slightly different and also the seating is all bar seating. Rotations are fast so even if all of the seats are taken you should be able to get a seat fairly quickly.We started with the pork belly which was super tender and full of flavor. The udon was wonderful and the broth was light. I ordered a soft boiled egg which came in shell. I made a slight mess getting it into my bowl. Tip: Normally when I order a soft boiled egg for noodles, it comes in the soup already. Here they provide a cold pre-boiled soft egg in shell. Make a small crack and  let the egg pour out for the broth to cook it.

uCEbXqeVBASuSISnJ0nqPA.text: kamo udon is very tasty. daily special is available.

-azLvxuAMl67D75d1wRKKw.text: Onsen Tamago!!! Yuuuuuhmmnm! Crazily a new colleague and I happened to get talking about where she a group of friends could go for dinner, I thought well B.I.N.G.O,  you're talking to the right girl. I gave her a few of my favourites to think about and she in return, mentioned Koya, "Oh yeah they do this amazing poached egg". Eggs, d.d..d...did you say poached egg? I had to explain about my sheer devotion to this food group, my favourite thing, poached eggs. I usually pass the Koya Restaurant's round the block queues, yearning for the day I may be able to get a coveted table, at this, no bookings eatery.  However at noon, I breezed straight in to the Koya Bar and was warmly welcomed and talked through the menu, chatted to the chefs prepping and had a lovely time. It was a great atmosphere to get some work done before a meeting, very calming, zen you might say. The poached egg was unusually cold, but still runny in a tasty miso broth. I chose a seaweed salad and barely battered, battered artichoke heart, in a crispy veil of tempura, served with an intriguing pinch of smokey aromatic grits. Really precise subtle clean flavours. I could appreciate every amount of effort in every morsel. There was a contented hush among the early smattering of diners all very much contemplating the flavours.A little pricey but worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Onsen tamago

2tR8XDgIUwQ54QPrzYY9RA.text: Not that great despite the long queue. I ordered a tempura udon and literally got a bowl of noodles with 1 prawn. It was quite pathetic, and seriously not worth £12 (including service charge). Wasn't impressed with the broth as well, it tasted only slightly better than what I get at my school canteen.

xLeVDTnMz7ndBLUhyxj4bA.text: Koya and Koya bar are next to each other makes it very difficult to not compare. If I were to go to Koya bar as an independent experience, I'll probably give it 5 star. But if I were to compare with the food next door, it would only deserve 4. I was at Koya couple weeks ago and had a bomb duck udon. I loved it soooo much I ordered the same dish. Unfortunately, the duck is a bit dough-ie and it's not the rare juicy duck breast at Koya. The soup and udon are still out of the world yum!It boils down to : if there is not a line, go to Koya, but if there is, the bar will do the job.

ytdVbnvVs6UnFYkUTARMJw.text: Went once and have come back so many times since! Bar to eat at. Fresh made udon. I go for breakfast usually.I would recommend the kedgereee and a simple udon...but to be honest that's all i've been able to try because it's so good I keep ordering it! So maybe it's not the best thing on the menu, but I wouldn't know because it's so good I can't resist ordering it every time.Only downside is that it's a bit pricey. but what else can you expect for great food in central london?

que6eYLgaZ0XxIosyw-xBA.text: We went without reservations on a Thursday evening. Koya Bar, the more Japanese-looking and smaller sister of Koya restaurant next door, was packed and busy. We thought we would have no chance of getting seated, but Koya Bar proved us wrong.Call it luck or great management, the accommodating manager sat us within 10 minutes upon arrival and, during the wait, gave us beers and water.Koya specializes in freshly made udon served many ways (hot udon in hot broth, cold udon in hot broth, cold udon in cold dipping sauce, etc), and at Koya Bar, you would see the udon made in front of you.We shared Kaiso (mixed seaweed) salad and Atsu-Age (fried and grilled tofu). I didn't care for the seaweed salad too much, but the tofu was nicely done. The highlight was indeed the udon. The Kinoko Hiya-Atsu (cold udon served with a hot mushroom broth along with walnut miso) was fantastic. The udon was chewy and easy to eat, one could easily taste the shiitake mushrooms in the broth, and the walnut miso was extraordinary (sweet and savory). Perhaps I don't know any better, but my only minor gripe was that it was challenging to combine the walnut miso with the udon and the broth. Once the miso was in the broth, I couldn't taste the flavor so much, so I mostly ate the miso separately from the rest.The prices were a bit high, but for fresh and delectable udons, it was totally worth it.

MtjPBb3Rdduwg3-Fce3uxg.text: Everything about this place was great. Food, Sake, lay out. Everything. The pork belly is crazy good.

Trrux8I8i6nf3lD_0N7ZbA.text: Came here for lunch with some friends. Ordered a variety of dishes.Firstly it must be said that the udon here is very good, even better than at Koya next door, perhaps because many of the original staff there have moved across to Koya Bar.I had the Niku Udon which is a hot udon in hot broth with thinly sliced beef, atsu atsu style! I enjoyed it very much and will definitely come back on a cold day. The noodles are freshly made in front of you and very springy and a bit chewy.I also had the Ten Mori which is a tempura assortment. This was delicious, the batter light and crispy, and the prawn and vegetables fresh. My only niggle is that it is just a bit oily, and perhaps they could pat it down a bit before serving.I tried my friends side of the Fish and Chips. Unfortunately this was disappointing. Firstly they forgot we ordered it, small mistake. But for the dish itself, the fish was average and a small portion. The chips were a type of tempura yam. It tasted nice but was incredibly greasy. We had two bites of the chips and left the rest.The menu at Koya Bar has a good range of items and is reasonably priced. I will be back should I want some hot udon!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Greasy greasy chips!
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Ten Mori Tempura
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Niku Udon

RSzM30LeHvWr3eErv8fp6A.text: Exactly the same menu as the original Koya restaurant next door, except that you sit at the kitchen bar. Its also a different queue, so if there's a long one at Koya, come here instead!Service was a bit slow though, but the food was awesome as usual. Miso buto udon is my favourite - sweet pork marinated in miso... Mmm!One star taken off as they charge 12.5% service charge, when there really is minimal service.

_2wzOjtvXyFU7Jp2ckA_jg.text: There were 6 workers in the bar but only 2 male workers cooked the food.  They prepared the food very very slowly.  You have to wait more than 20 minutes for just two bowls of udon. The udon is only subpar.Do not recommend this place, unless you like to wait and have no place to go.

mJ-fAR6Gfl6Aqp1wZXOwIw.text: Honestly so confusing and I think a lot of customers are posting the wrong photos in the wrong restaurant as there are sister restaurants right next to each other!  Both look great but don't get confuse. I am honestly not that impressed with the udon, maybe I just don't love udon anymore and I prefer pho... I am over the big thick noodles and soup lacking in flavour. I felt that the noodle soup was a bit expensive as £10.50 for a average bowl of noodle and tiny bit if beef, I was not impressed. Order something else or try elsewhere.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

2BSVCUJxIVFA2rrpp8HThA.text: Amazing Udon, amazing place, amazing staff. They have a really nice donburi even it being a udon specialized place. The texture of the udon I'd amazing as well.

CXwIx-89d8Nq0pmjAzzo5Q.text: I know these days ramen is all the hype. I don't care. I am an udon girl through and through!Having just come back from Japan, based on a direct comparison, Koya Bar's specialized udon really holds its own against indigenous udon from the Land of the Rising Sun.I'll state Koya's single downside first. The wait can be long because they don't take reservations, and this joint is RIDICULOUSLY popular. However, if you're coming with a small party (under 3 people), you will be seated MUCH more quickly. In any case, they manage the line very well, making sure nobody cuts and everyone is accommodated in a fair order, so no complaints really.Now, THE FOOD. They have a diverse selection of different broths, each complex and unique in its flavor. Gingery, meaty, bright, Koya's broths are excellent.The texture of the udon too was amazing. Each noodle strand was formulated and cooked to perfection. If you had tempura, it was crispy and hot, but started getting that delicious melty texture when immersed in the broth.I recommend always getting some of the fresh specials on their seasonal menu. Everything is carefully curated, and there's something at Koya for everyone! Carnivores, vegans (but why.), locals, foreigners, etc.I can't write anymore because I'll start drooling, but if you're visiting and don't know what to eat, this is a fantastic option. If you're a London local, shame on you if you haven't visited here yet.I HAVE SPOKEN.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. 2015. Back for more.
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Delicious vegetable tempura ^__^
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Fresh fresh FRESH veggies!

CkIgB8Op29VrmQ7PmI5BOw.text: Hidden away at the heart of Soho is a little piece of Japan. With its simple design, it's not much of a looker and you might have passed it hundreds of times without even realising. But behind Koya's traditional curtain is one of London's most authentic Japanese restaurants. No sushi here though; Koya focuses on home-style food, especially udon noodles, of which they offer dozens of variations. All made in-house and absolutely delicious!The atmosphere is unlike anything I'd ever experienced in any other London restaurant before. It's just so quiet and pieceful. No doubt you'll leave very full and extremely relaxed!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pickled apple special at Koya Bar
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Koya Bar
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork & miso udon at Koya Bar

6ZR3eerpyCAzwabvCIsPDg.text: Koya bar is a beautiful little eatery containing an open kitchen and walled off by a bar with high stools for seating on the other side so customers can watch food being prepared. It is a good representation of what one is usually like in Japan with it's wooden decor and small seating space. As well as serving udon they are only a few places in London that serves traditional Japanese breakfast every day of the week opening as early as 8:30am to accommodate that. They also have a special menu that changes regularly including grilled fish of the day and serve a variety of traditional dishes for lunch and dinner as well The problem is that not all of the staff are friendly. Some can be quite stern, short and abrupt, giving service without a smile. Kedgeree This was a creative fusion of the original dish and using short grain rice and a lot of water content to create it instead. It was more like Chinese congee texture. Sadly flavours didn't realyl deliver, lacking depth and umami.  The chunks of cured haddock were quite a nice addition adding saltiness although quite dense in texture, losing too much of it's moisture from the curing process. Curry flavour was mild but a nice touch of bonito flakes on the side for a burst of flavour. A poached egg to add that creaminess in replacement of butter and cream like the original kedgeree recipe. It was a creative dish but the broth base needs to be stronger, to add depth and flavourCurry udon This was very satisfying. Probably not a breakfast dish itself but I love it. The udon were thick, bouncy and a nice long length which made it great for slurping. The curry itself was fragrant, rich and thick, attaching itself to every strand of udon. It was mild in spice which allowed big warm soothing mouthfuls to capture all the lovely flavour. The few broccoli florets it came with was nicely grilled and soft, giving a nice sweet smokiness to the curry udon. Japanese breakfast Is was very like how they serve it traditionally in Japan although a more formal breakfast nowadays. A bit disappointed with the pickles being the generic pickled beetroot rather than daikon or turnips. As much as I love beetroot I do hope to experience more traditional vegetables that you would receive in Japan. The grilled fish of the day that came with the set was brill which was cured nicely, flakey and meaty. Went well with a simple bowl of rice and a lovely freshly made miso soup with deep fried silken tofu and carrot for a nice subtle sweetness.I did very much enjoy my experience at Koya bar although I felt many improvements could have been made as well. Staff need to be more hospitable as it was the reason why my partner rated this place a two. Kedgeree needed more depth and the cured fish inside could have been more softer. The menu is full of creativity but then it leads me to question why they use ready made pickled beetroot rather than pickling their own. Still, going to Koya bar evolved some nostalgic memories of days in Japan, wanting a quick and easy bowl of udon.

QurxTs5XpUF_oG_dHogICA.text: Koya Bar, Frith Street - Koya Bar is a proper Japanese noodle bar. In the night of Soho lights, it sits humbly among the other eateries with their attractive and catchy signs. A black shop front with large glass window and a one door entrance, it would have been easier to keep an eye out for their logo. Did it attract any less customers? No, in fact, queues can build up easily as seating are limited. Koya Bar does not take reservations and you will only be seated when all of your companions have arrived.fish and chips £9.10 - served as a starter, small plate, sharing style it is the Koya's take on English fish and chips. Brilliant! I suspect that the chips were from a sweet vegetable like plantain or sweet potato. It was feather light like the batter on the fish. No vinegar or tomato sauce but served with their dipping sauce of radish and spring onions, it was so delicious that we didn't stop eating until the plate was empty. kamonabe (duck and vegetable hot pot) £14.30 - from a spectator's view, I thought that they were a little mean on the duck and vegetable. My dining companion confirmed that it had the proper proportion of udon to filling to broth. It was good but the broth was a little on the oily side.hiya-hiya zaru udon tenzaru (cold udon with cold sauce to dip with prawn and vegetable tempura) £13.90 - after the fish and chips, I was glad that I chose the tempura to go with my noodles. It was delightfully crispy and each bite into the batter was so satisfying. The kind of batter that possibly every OCD foodie/chef is trying to create at home. I give up, and will just dine here from now on. The assortment of vegetables were all but one slightly undercooked.With Koya Bar, it was more than just the food. The place exudes the Japanese culture of eating and looking around the place for a moment, I could be fooled that we were in Japan. Koya Bar was full and most had their heads down totally engrossed in their bowls of udon, I was quite amazed that a steaming hot broth noodles was favoured equally well in the West as in Asia. I thought it was only the kind of dish only understood by the Asians. Seating by the bar might not be suitable on certain occasions - like if you have a crowd of friends  or have sharing dishes - but on second thoughts, sitting opposite someone who slurps their noodles is not particularly inviting. I still have to work my way through the menu - udon noodles being the main which comes with different toppings, rice in donburi style and various small plates to choose from. Not to mention that there are specials from time to time. What seemed like a small portion of noodles turned out to be quite filling and with a small plate to share between the two of us, I was full. A good place for simple yet flavoursome food. No desserts served and I did find myself wanting one.Koya Bar exudes a casualness with personality and integrity. It is not the kind of glamorous place with awkward formalities, numerous cutlery, hostile service and an expensive menu that makes you think twice but if I were taken on a date here, I am glad to walk away with the date that knows and has good taste!Will I be back for more? You can certainly count on it!

-x34lgPTDSW8qsuHz_qNkA.text: The food was super underwhelming. Noodles were under cooked and service was rushed. Would not recommend this place at all.

7vWVraMbKCtMsnAlfpM-_A.text: We didn't have to wait too long for a seat early evening on a Sunday night. It's all bar seating (as the name implies) and udon is good as always. I went for the tempura hiya atsu (cold noodles, hot soup and it was way more than enough food. The tempura plate is a pretty decent size. The noodles are awesome - and if you're an udon fan you won't find any complaints! As always, pork kakuni is amazing, but a bit pricey for the small amount you get.

98YJLPOWrRtyoHauMigxpg.text: Stopped in for quick lunch before heading to the Harry Potter play.  Unfortunately breakfast was over and they only had a lunch menu available.  I had the mushroom/miso/walnut cold udon in hot broth and my husband got the pork hot udon. The soup was clean, simple, uncomplicated and delicious.  I don't understand the whole hot udon/hot broth vs. cold udon/hot broth since I ultimately dumped all my cold udon into the hot broth, but overall two thumbs up.   It's a very small space so plan to come early or wait.

Zjov07D-CGNltaOLh4RJkw.text: I was excited to try this place but the broth just did not taste good at all... for a ramen place that was very disappointing and just not worth the pricey food. Not worth the hype.

8ZOY2bO1LD_xg39YEIQv0g.text: Very frustrating experience. We came and were told to sit outside. Apparently we should have lined up and 15 people went ahead of us. When I told the hostess she did not honor that we had been there longer than anyone and was not apologetic.

XFNlAEgtPCsxcXuWnXUURA.text: I knew I was in for a treat when I entered a very Japanese-looking noodle shop and was greeted with "irasshaimase!" The menu looked traditional, obviously besides the English breakfast udon, and I had a hard time choosing just one bowl. I settled on the kitsune udon with onsen tamago and the fish that was written on the daily special. Maybe it was because I arrived at the odd time of 11:50 (right between breakfast and lunch), but I think my order took a long time. Another couple arrived after I was nearly finished and they seemed to receive their order in less than half the time I did. The egg was cooked perfectly, with a yolk that only barely kept its shape in the broth and the whites were just wisps. I finished almost all of the soup and the noodles had a great texture, as did the tofu. Just like in Japan. However, I have to say I was a little disappointed with the fish. It was delicious and nicely grilled, but I didn't feel it was worth £9 even though it came with some lovely pickles. But I guess London is expensive and that should be expected. I would definitely come here again when the udon craving hits, though I will stick to the udon and show up at a more reasonable hour.

rVDCZEIjQr3SnMZWQUik4w.text: Delicious udon and very nice beer. I had a mushroom and walnut udon soup. Cold udon and hot broth with walnuts on the side which you mix in. All aspects were great and I added a spoonful of spice to give it a bit of a kick. The Kirin beer was more expensive than usual but when it came I realised the price was because it was the premium brew and it was really delicious. Only reason it didn't get five stars is cos the place is a little small for its popularity and it was a little warm in there because of the open kitchen, which I like, but could have used some air.

e5t0Wl-OBEQ_wESjYX7INA.text: I think I have tried udon noodles in every city or town I've ever lived in, so to say that I'm a fan of udon is very much an understatement. Having now qualified myself as an udon expert, I think Koya Bar serves some of the best noodles I've had! Thick, chewy, freshly made noodles in tastefully made broths, with some nice surprise small plates that change often (keeps visits fun, right?).As a pescetarian, my options are more limited due to not being able to have the dishes made with pork broth. I usually order the curry or the mixed seaweed and both are delicious every time. The ingredients (veg and seaweed) actually change according to the season and what they have in the kitchen, so I'm actually never bored. In the curry, sometimes I'll get pumpkin, or squash, or aubergines, and the seaweed selection is never quite the same. Other people seem to really like their walnut miso and mushroom dish, so any lover of mushroom (which I am not) might like to try that one since it does come recommended. The cold noodles are also wonderful if you're craving a particularly chewy texture. Refreshing and just right for a warm day. My husband loves a variety of their meat options, by the way.I think there are a few people who complain that the flavour can be very bland and the portions too small. I've never had a problem with a less salty dish, to be honest. I've always loved the more subtle and cleaner tasting broth. I've had many udon soups in Japan itself and found those to be way too salty. I guess it's just a matter of preference! As for the portion, they're not huge and quite pricey, which is why my rating is a 4 rather than a 5, but I always thought the servings were just about right. That might just be me, though!You can also fill up on the smaller plates, some which have been yummy, others that have been misses. It's when you get the 'misses' that hurt because of the hefty price, but I've never had one that was downright terrible.In general, I like the former Koya restaurant better because the options for the small plates were always very good, but since that's closed now, this is now my go-to place when my udon craving kicks in. And I'm still pretty happy about that.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Artichoke tempura with mint salt. SO good.
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Curry udon goodness

z3NJ7213p1_B7AsDwclfhQ.text: Trendy Japanese place with an innovative take on British fish and chips (light, thinner, smaller-- delicious) and a shockingly good beef udon. Not to mention a very decent set of rice bowls, shrimp tempura in particular.The beef was amazing, the udon broth was good, the only real weakness was the noodles-- compared to how amazing the beef was, the udon was only somewhat above average. Perhaps it sat in the bowl a little too long while I took pictures-- that could be entirely my fault...One long bar, glass front, not quite elbow to elbow over steaming bowls of rice and noodle soup. About the way it should be, yet with the glass storefront giving a bit of entirely appropriate European flair.

qnQ_z6eilQIF53YLj5hPqg.text: Came here for breakfast on the weekend, at first glance you get the feel you are at one of the more contemporary ramen bars you get in Tokyo near a train station.I come in and hear the usual 'irashimasen' welcoming you into the restaurant, although here it was a bit limp and unenthusiastic (compared to the roar you get in Japan).We weren't welcomed in by anyone so walked up to the bar to ask for a seat and that we had a reservation but the waitress just looked at us as if we insulted her. For a second, I thought I had said something to scare her but I really hadn't. After eventually coming to an agreement that we want to sit and eat, we found the menu already on the table for us and a bottle of tap water, it's always good when you don't have to ask for water so when it was automatically provided, I was glad and it took away a bit of the bad feelings my initial experience left me with. Also free water is commonplace in Japan, you will pretty much always get free water or even tea sometimes.The food for breakfast was ok, there was nothing wrong with it. Kind of resembled Japanese food but lacking some of the flavours and scents that you experience in Japan. Textures were fairly reminiscent of Japan and it was enjoyable at the very least if you like eating at the bar rather than at a table. The price was too high for what it was, would be at least half of this even in Tokyo and the portions would be bigger.I witnessed the 2 waitresses, including the one that we first encountered, have generally bad manners and poor behaviour towards customers the whole time we were there.Good service goes hand in hand with Japanese dining and this place failed miserably on that front. Waited about 10 minutes to finally get the attention of someone to ask for the bill even after direct eye contact and me asking for the bill several times. I payed, although the whole transaction was so awkward, I felt like I had asked something incredibly unreasonable, maybe they prefer you to not pay? I don't know, Koya was good 3 years ago, sadly I don't have any desire to return. Only come here if you don't care about service.

q-a2sziAGSHwhDzeHhPubQ.text: I have fond memories of coming to this place when I used to live here, so I was quite surprised to walk in and find a strange new place (it used to look like this: s3-media4.fl.yelpcdn.com…)Gone is the family-style 4-to-a-table seating arrangement, now everyone sits at a bar counter behind which the food is cooked. Based on the other Yelp reviews I've read, it seems like there was a management change or something in the last few years. I suppose the new seating arrangement makes more sense financially - an added perk is that it feels much less intimidating to go eat on your own, as the old setup meant you were occupying an entire table by yourself, or felt like you had to make small talk with the other individuals put at your table. That said, don't even bother trying to come here with more than 3 people, you'll be left waiting for a while.Udon itself is a fairly simple dish, it's noodles dumped in broth, with meat/vegetables, and garnish, so it's quite easy to make but very difficult to master. While the udon I got (cold noodles in hot broth with beef) was quite good, it didn't have the same depth or "WOW" factor that made me remember the place five years later and want to come back. Or maybe I'm just getting senile with age. I'm glad they didn't chock the whole thing full of MSG like so many other places that serve udon though, I could actually drink the broth without feeling like I needed to down an entire bottle of still water (which they do provide you with, free)Still, for a SoHo-area restaurant, the prices were fairly affordable. It took a little while for me to place an order, but at least the bill came fairly quick. Also, there's a guest wifi network, but there's no wifi password anywhere to be seen. What gives?Verdict: Not bad, good as a no-frills go-to place, but I'd still come back.Yay: Good for individuals, prices, very little to no MSG in the brothNay: Not good for groupsMeh: It wasn't as good as I remembered it to be

THPnfKVAQuO6_p8W7PhLag.text: I totally ordered wrong but I am not going to let that get in the way of appreciating what Koya Bar is.  I've eaten at the location next door and quality here is also top notch. I stumbled in right before lunch and they were still serving breakfast.  I should have stuck with some of the other tasty looking, more traditionally Japanese fare on offer but thought I'd try their English Breakfast udon.  It's a bowl of their lovely broth and toothsome noodles topped with an egg (runny yolk!!), two pieces of streaky bacon and three small shitake mushrooms.  Everything was perfectly prepared.  I'm just not sure they all should have been in the same bowl!  Nonetheless, I finished it all.  When I come back, I'll definitely try some of their more traditional fare instead.As others have said, not a locale for group dining.  Best as a couple or alone.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

36q1IM0o8-ObH-Ir81kKsg.text: I didn't know there's a place in London where you can have Japanese breakfast. We were there before lunch hour so we managed to get a seat straight away on a Saturday. If you are here for lunch on a weekend I would suggest to come early cuz there are not many seats. I only had the breakfast which is simple and tasty. I would like to come again for the udon.

-U68ELHzso_UK2b0PX6WjA.text: I had kyu (beef) udon, and it was solid. My favourite part of it was the broth -- just adequately flavoured and fatty without being too thick or heavy. There was a good portion of well-cooked beef as well. Overall, a very good bowl of udon that hit the spot for me. Ambience was casual -- all seats were along the bar, where food was served over the counter. A bit on the small side in terms of space, but perhaps, this adds to the low-key, local feel of it all. Service was relatively prompt and good. We had to wait for about 15mins to get a seat on a Sunday afternoon around 1:30pm, so just be mindful of the timing before you go!

tbOBICxTq1Y5IkwAbDi_Rw.text: I love udon, chefs love this place, so was I going to love this place?  Hmmm unfortunately I tried Koya Bar for breakfast a few months after returning from Japan so it had some tough competition. The udon noodles are good, with a nice bounce and bite.  They should be given the effort Koya takes in creating them!  The soup though was lacking, overly delicate.  At these prices for a bowl of udon it needs to be great.  For around 1/4 of Koya Bar's prices in the reputedly expensive country of Japan you can get much better with flavoursome and rich soup packed with meat, fish, sweet and salty flavours.Even without considering price comparisons Koya didn't knock my socks off and I love udon.  So maybe I'm just not a chef.

Oehtvv8vC4cv0iKPZ5bW_w.text: I get why people like this place.  Hip, open kitchen and bar sitting which is the in thing nowadays.  I have tried the pork belly as a starter but I was not really impressed by it.  3 pieces of pork belly which I expect to be tender but the meat was slightly dry and on the hard side.  The udon had a good bite to it which is as expected.  In any udon meal, the broth must be the highlight but it was just a normal broth for me.  Nothing too exciting and it was a slightly small bowl for the price that I pay.  I have tried Ichiryu which to me has a slightly better broth and extremely good value for money especially during its happy hour.  I guess I need to come back again to try other dishes but they did not provide a good impression for me during my first round.  Good selection of udon though so it should cater for everyone.  They open during breakfast as well which is very rare for an udon / Japanese establishment so it should provide a different breakfast adventure for people.  Not just the same old British breakfast.

GBZcPir8wnP55kPlAtQF7g.text: I came to Koya on a late Friday afternoon afternoon after arriving in London. There was no wait and I was promptly seated by the bar. I ordered Niku Udon, which is soup udon topped with sliced beef and green onions. The beef was tender, the udon was chewy, and the broth was light and savory. Exactly what I needed after a long flight! Will definitely come again if I have the chance.

GFTPIkTny5js95RY9Z6CPw.text: This is a nice place to enjoy some light food.  Cold or hot udon in a hot brooth with different Japanese sides. My favourite is the cold udon with any tempura on the side. The udon is chewy and favourable. I also had a chance to try their beef don. Compared to what I had in Toronto, this place served a lighter version of beef don, in which doesn't give you a heavy kinda aftertaste. I will definitely go back once again before I left London.

eg99M8SUEKXY-3ZGL-0XTw.text: Udon here is top notch! I'd advise getting the tamago (poached egg) to add to your noodles.  It definitely elevates the dish.  I was here for business for about 2 weeks and came back here twice in that time! It's perfect for those cold London days.

Z61vwP1Bg3eckJxS2XdqkA.text: Really good Udon bar!The food is simple and tasty.Im more a ramen person but Udob here is gooood and comes in all types.I went for the pork and miso hot udon and hot broth with and a extra of poached egg.It was a bit sweet but I loved that the poached egg came in shell and I had to crack it in the bowl is quircky and fun.Would defo come back to try other dishes!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork and miso udon with poached egg

h4KR5cysvtYwDjpK0LlBMQ.text: yrscore: F5/E4.5/R5One of the best udon I have ever tasted in London. I particularly like the cold noodle in hot broth. The tempura was very well cooked too. Fresh prawn and vegetable with good batter. The experience was fantastic. There are limited seats in Koya. This is because the setting is of a bar style. You get to see the chef preparing it right in front of your eyes. The only thing that I have to comment is the friendliness of the staffs. Perhaps due to the busy-ness of the restaurant, I feel that the staffs can be a tad friendlier. Despite that, I would definitely return to this place for the food and experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

eC3kud3JGrgSgYkmvVs-wQ.text: ~ Waited about 20m at 8pm on a Wednesday+ Kakuni was fantastic, melt-in-your-mouth pork+ Udon was very simple, but very good. Broth had good flavor, noodles had perfect texture~ I'd come back to try the rotating specials

j1QuLIWRiwG3__kWBDA45g.text: Really enjoyed this place. I haven't had udon in a while and this was better than I remembered.I got a classic - cold udon noodles with miso and pork broth - really tasty broth with chunks of pork mince and a faint taste of sherry? Some sort of booze but it tastes divine. While I was waiting I also had a miso soup (was very hungover and needed all of the liquids). When you sit down at the bar you get a 1/2 litre bottle of water which is always a nice touch.Besides the broth, which was really excellent, I was surprised with the tofu in my miso, I always think MEH when I think tofu and this was very good.As for queues and timing, I went at 6.30 and there were 4 people ahead of me in the queue. By the time I left there were at least 20, so I guess it pays off to come early or at a weird dining time. Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Cold udon with pork and miso broth

tLhhIrOKtoLZRM_cMjLWDQ.text: Their udons were amazing here. It's perfect to go in on a rainy/cold day and just sit and order a bowl of hot udon. I ordered the tempura udon and it was quite refreshing. It's a small place inside and bar seating only, but worth the wait if they're busy.

RBGGW7y1BRNXSzoaOHfKTA.text: We rolled in on a Tuesday evening at 6:30 to a line outside the restaurant. It moved through quickly and menus were read as we waited (clearly they're on a mission to feed the masses!) We were ushered to the bar and squeezed in on low stools - it was a bit cramped but it's all part of the charm. Tonnes of vegetarian options on the menu and it's fun to watch the flurry of activity in the kitchen. The udon noodles were heavenly and the vegetable tempura was right there in the clouds too. Would strongly recommend! Go in feeling patient and willing to squeeze at small tables for amazing food.

U0qU2d48r_QWeHFxBRtlAg.text: I am spoiled for Asian food because I live in Vancouver.  Koya definitely hit the spot for authentic Japanese udon while on holidays.  I had the kitsune udon in soup. The broth is clean tasting.  The udon had the perfect bounce.  The only thing is what should be the sweet soy tofu skin was more like a sweet soy marinated tofu so it wasn't truly authentic.  Alas, quite pricey for what it is but I am still happy to pay up for some delicious udon.

a3Pe5HkMBCWEaRUeXjfbqA.text: Arrived around 7:45pm on a Tuesday, and about 5 groups ahead of us. Line moved slow, contrary to what other reviews noted. It's a small place, seating consists of just a long bar around the kitchen space. We ordered the prawn and vegetable tempura to start, which was perfect. The batter was light and crispy. The prawns were ginormous and meaty, definitely the largest prawns I've ever seen in a tempura platter. We ordered the ktisune udon and the pork miso udon (both hot), perfect for a cold winter evening. The broths were simple, light, and very tasty. The noodles were cooked perfectly and slurped down quite quickly.While the food was tasty, I had to minus one star for the service. The wait staff was extremely friendly, but so slow. It took us a good 15 minutes after being seated for someone to take our order. Granted there were only 2 waiters for the small place, and just two cooks.

Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Kitsune udon (tofu slab)
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork miso udon

azIWXut6YD1op8imKdjobA.text: As many people do, the husband and I heavily rely on reviews. We decided to wing it this morning. We decided that after a long month and a half we needed some Asian food. We walked past and decided to give a Japanese Breakfast a try. The food isn't horrible, but the food is not worth the price. I understand that it is Soho, but then I expect something with flavors that wow. I was not quite sure whether to be pleased or to be disappointed about the time that we needed to wait for the food to be prepared. There were three other people in the restaurant.We ordered the Curry Udon and the Japanese Breakfast. I had different expectations for $34 breakfast without alcohol. For example to actually feel comfortably full or to get bouncy/chewy udon noodle. The curry was not bad but the udon noodles were a bit overdone. Maybe the lunch and evening menu are a better bang for your buck/pound.

uT8kwwU-2jH9fNsjwwJ_TQ.text: Second time at Koya bar to try another japanese breakfast. This place does savoury things only and if the thought of eating fish for breakfast doesn't set you off, well this is worth a try.They have 3 types of breakfasts: udon noodles; rice porridge (all with different toppings) or a japanese menu with grilled fish, pickles, rice and miso soup.First time we tried the menu and unfortunatly the fish (mackerel) was very very dry so we were a bit disappointed. If you want to give it a try, ask what the fish of the day is (second time they had haddock and it didn't look dry).We also tried the udon (egg and soya sauce for me) and the rice porridge (spring onions, haddock and egg for him) and that was delicious. Quite pricey but good idea for a special occasion breakfast (£24 for 2 meals and 2 teas).Service is a bit slow - but they do cook everything in front of you so it helps pass the time.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Kedgeree (Rice porridge with haddock, egg and curry)
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Tama Kama (Udon noodles with egg and soya sauce)

ZGWnvMe-zorVqXJ0jT2AGQ.text: This was a fairly good restaurant that seems like it's popular with locals. Seating is limited so waiting may be expected during your visit here. That is, if you can find the restaurant since there wasn't a big sign or anything noting where the restaurant is located.We ordered 1 pork and miso ramen and 1 vegetable tempura donburi. This wasn't our first pick since we were wanting beef but they ran out of beef at 6:15 PM when we were seated. Bill was around £27.The food was pretty good except the pork and miso ramen didn't have much pork in it and little veggies. Next time I come, I would maybe order something else.Overall, pretty popular restaurant and would recommend if in the area wanting some Asian food but they ran out of chicken AND beef by the time we left at 7:00.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork And Miso Udon
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Vegetable Donburi with Miso Soup

4D6VuzPTjUTLTqfINhlcYA.text: This was the only restaurant I repeated during my last trip to London, and it was absolutely worth it. My boyfriend and I started with the kakuni, which was mouthwateringly tender, juicy, and fatty (just the right amount!). I've daydreamed about this dish so much. I chose the udon special that night, which had fried garlic ramps and onsen tamago--delicious! The broth was well-balanced and not overly salty, and the noodles were perfectly cooked. I'll definitely be coming back on my next trip.Service was also prompt and friendly! The second time I came, their credit card machine wasn't working because of network issues, but they were very patient and accommodating. Luckily, I brought cash!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast udon special
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Udon special with fried garlic ramps and onsen tamago.

pPynARQgAD_sIvO8NRUing.text: Hands down, the best meal we had in London. We each had a bowl of udon, mine with sweet tofu, my husband's I don't really remember because I was so into mine :) But he loved it too haha. Anyway, sweet tofu udon was on point. Sweet tofu was one whole slab of tofu and udon was cooked perfectly. The bowl was a lot bigger than it looked, so I ate slowly and ended up having overcooked udon by the end. We had some delicious udon in Honolulu, which was rated one of the best in the states, but Koya Bar definitely has them beat :) Then we shared a pork belly. And it was amazingg. Usually the fat in pork belly makes me feel so guilty that I cannot enjoy it, but this was the most tender, melt in your mouth meat that the fat was the perfect compliment. It came with this generous serving of fresh wasabi, that was just as impressive as the rest of the meal. I cannot recommend Koya Bar enough. Long lines during prime dinner times, but so worth the wait.

CvXORRnMdUPiIVh0Xx3lOQ.text: Koya Bar is a small Japanese restaurant which doesn't have tables, instead it has a long bar. The food is good and the interior is good too, you get to see the chefs cooking whilst you're waiting for your bowl of yummy soup or rice.I went for a Donburi dish, which was good! The taste was good and it was filling enough. You can see from my photo that the dish looks tasty, and it was! My friend had a bowl of udon which he thought was very good. To conclude.. This restaurant isn't just good for Udon, it's good for Donburi too! I'm just giving 3/5 because I wasn't mind-blown, and the restaurant's music playing was simply Radio 1, which was too loud and lost the authentic Japanese experience.I will go back to eat more!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

_K1EoB-MGpVsuQ8ZQBVovA.text: Awesome udon and sake, very authentic and yet casual ambience -an all-around great place for delicious Japanese food in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Delicious food, friendly staff, lovely Japanese ambience.

GgFjvAB5cKu_BuenMh-sqg.text: Kedgeree with a side order of umeboshi and Japanese hot tea!  What a hearty breakfast!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

ImXecQlgmjbZrZrnJQ7fTg.text: Koya is a small, authentic Japanese noodle bar specialising in all sorts of udon. Seating is around a long bar table facing the cooking area which can give you a nice glimpse of the chef preparing your dish. My friend and I both got the buta miso (his favourite) which is hot udon with pork and miso as well as a couple of sharing plates. The udon noodles itself is thick and with a lovely texture, and the hot broth held a lot of flavour. The pork is sweet which was surprising but worked well overall with the dish. Bear in mind, an udon dish is quite simple! It's quite literally thick, flat noodles plopped into a bowl of broth and a spoon of topping dumped over it but the magic is in the depth of flavour that contains. The only turn off was the price. The udon itself is alright - a bowl costs around £10 - but the small plates tend to be quite pricey. A plate of a few pieces of vegetable tempura and 2 pieces of prawn cost a whopping £12. Definitely not good value. Not entirely sure if I will revisit. There are other more affordable Japanese joints in this city which might take precedence.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Vegetable and prawn tempura
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Hot udon with hot broth and pork

wYlLqqDII3Czd8-1qPXMVg.text: This brought me back to the fabulous udon shops in Kyoto, Tokyo, and O'ahu.  Actually, the udon here may the best of the lot.  I'd recommend: - Buta Miso Atsu-Atsu:  hot broth with hot udon noodles, and a really umami-packed, subtle yet aromatic miso with ground pork, really the best miso soup I've ever had, and it went so well with the perfectly chewy thick udon noodles- Hiyashi Kinoko Udon:  a beautiful nest of chewy thick udon noodles, topped with tender enoki and shiitake and other mushrooms, thinly ribboned shiso leaf, with a little wasabi on the side for you to add as you choose (I put it all in and it added just the right level of spice), then you poor on top of this art piece a delicious, fragrant soy and dashi esque broth.  It is just pure deliciousness, the thing dreams are made of.  - The prawn and vegetable tempura were very well done, with light batter, and not oily, the perfect side to share with two.  It has two large prawns, and one large piece each of eggplant (super tender), broccoli (really crisp and flavorful), cauliflower, zucchini, and shishito pepper.  The meal paired nicely with a semi-sparkling white Italian wine they served in a cute little can.  It's one long wooden noodle bar with perhaps 15 seats so there's a good kitchen view from all seats.  Efficient and friendly service.  No complaints here.  Can't wait to return!

sPiOpkuZhnVznP1AK4P-Yg.text: Decided to get some udon at Koya Soho with a friend on a Saturday. I got the Niku udon. The broth is lighter than I'd like and missing an umami quality a beef udon should have. Broth flavors were mainly ginger notes and dashi essence. Furthermore, the noodles were slightly overcooked and soft. I doubt the noodles are being made in house from scratch. I also ordered tanuki which is chopped up tempura bits. This topping lent a fried tempura-ness to the udon. The Niku (beef) itself was thin cut, rare and satisfactory, but nothing particularly remarkable. In addition to udon, my friend and I ordered kakuni, and tsukemono. Kakuni is served in a bowl, stewing in its own juices. A dab of wasabi on the side. Melty and fatty. Unami. Wasabi offers a spicy nuance. Mild salty seasoning. Tsukemono was also enjoyable, crunchy fermented greens and roots. Salty and tangy fermented character was an excellent palate cleanser for the meal.While I think the main attraction, the udon, is satisfactory at best, the sides are the hidden gems of the menu at Koya Soho.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Tanuki.
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Niku Udon.
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Tsukemono.

k5c-tcSg7aRF4HLkQiKmEA.text: We came here for dinner and fell in love. We got the kamo (duck and udon in hot broth), hiyashi kinoko (cold udon with marinated mushrooms and shiso, with cold broth on the side), tamago, prawn and vegetable tempura, and beef katsu. The udons were amazing, although we didn't get to try the one I had targeted going in (the hiyashi buta miso -- they were all out by the time we got there). The tempura is an absolute must as well. We really liked the katsu as well, although I'd be okay trying other stuff next time. (I had really wanted to try the fish & chips, but got overruled.)Great food, super authentic-feeling, and pretty well-priced.

xt8KgQ4sq0q-Wcnp94z1Hg.text: Hands down the best udon I have eaten outside of Japan. Truly an authentic and delicious meal.There was a long wait as there should be for a worthy meal in Soho on a Saturday night. As soon as I bit down into my tempura and noodles, I was home. It was all worth it.Fresh, crunchy tempura with giant prawns and vegetables. Delicate, flavourful noodles and dashi broth. The saba udon was hot, flaky and packed with umami. Beware of the lone fishbone. Otherwise you can go as slow as you want.My friend had the curry and it was thick and delicious. Very filling and enriching. My companion had the miso pork which had depth and a salty broth. Such a joy in every bite.I recommend this to anyone who wants to experience the best of Japanese cuisine in a bar setting. I cannot wait to return.

ff68lAnnZxUrpvnzk9iujQ.text: The udon noodles were fine, but we got there so early that we could only order from the limited breakfast menu. As a lover of udon, I was disappointed by the English breakfast udon. It was also severely overpriced.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

sTKS4T63ZJV2smMd7oLE6g.text: Koya Bar is worth trying if you're craving udon but don't have a flight ticket to Japan.The restaurant is small with only bar seating facing the open kitchen. If you don't mind waiting at least 30 minutes on a weekend night, then you'll find yourself deciding among a ton of udon options to try. The menu features a ton of options for your udon, whether you prefer it hot or cold, with broth or sauce, and different toppings. The food came pretty quickly after we ordered. My friend and I both got the cold udon with sesame sauce for dipping. This was delicious. The sesame sauce is thick and flavorful and the udon is firm and chewy. No matter what udon you choose, you also have to get the prawn and vegetable tempura. The tempura is crunchy and the prawns are huge and delicious! Each serving comes with two prawns so this is great for sharing too! The menu also featured some small plates. We tried the agedashi tofu, which was good but it uses hard tofu and I prefer soft tofu. Overall, I really enjoyed the udon and tempura here. Can't wait to return when I crave udon!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Agedashi tofu
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Cold udon with sesame sauce
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Prawn and vegetable tempura

xIrEk0VnjJ284rFiodqEdQ.text: FOOD+ Hiyashi buta udon: so good! The udon was of perfect bite/texture and the pour over sauce went well with it.iso pork was salty and a tiny bit sweetness so it was tasty when mixed into the noodles and the sauce. I added some green onions and then ginger whenever I wanted a little spicy kick. Radish on the side to clean my palate between bites of other food items+ Vegetable tempura: thought this was okay. The batter was light, still greasy especially with the starchy vegetables. Fairly large size order- attempted to order the "fish and chips" but they didn't have any that dayAMBIANCE/DECORCozy small shop with counter seating around the kitchen. Everything seems neat and tidy. I sat in front of the noodle chef who called out orders from time to time. The place was fairly quiet and patrons mainly dined alone or some with one other companion. No hooks under table for jackets or purses, but coat hooks on the wall to the right when you walk in. Restroom available was clean too.SERVICEGood service and food came at a good pace. I didn't have to wait long at all. I was asked to move one seat over because a small group of people came and wanted more space to sit together. I didn't hear the waitress tell them she will ask me to move over so I think it was the customers' request. It was fine. I'm not claustrophobic :)Are at my own pace and was not rushed to pay bill. Overall, I really liked their udon and would come back to try other items when I'm back in London! I even offered my husband to come for another meal (he's never been), but we decided to eat elsewhere the rest of our stay in London. So yea, I would recommend this place!

h9Uq2V47dUkPiuBE4p3FXA.text: I ate here today for lunch. I was impressed with the amount of udon served and the thick texture as well as the very tasty walnut miso. But the broth with mushrooms was pretty bland. For £13 I thought this meal was quite overpriced. The seating area is quite small and they don't take rez so expect a queue.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Udon with mushroom and walnut miso

64kQZX6QzjRl5zoGqU6M4g.text: OVERALL: Highly recommend if you enjoy udon! Casual spot but really high-quality Japanese Udon. Bar only seating so not suitable for big groups. Would be good for solo-dining. They have a ton of options for udon it's a bit overwhelming but also great way to get you to come back and try the different flavors. MUST-GET: Any of their udons! Probably go with the cold udon so it's chewier. Although when it's cold outside, it's nice to just have a large bowl of hot udon and soup. I really enjoyed the Niku udon. I love their clear soup, it's not too oily like most ramen soup and it's very refreshing. Their tempura is also delicious! Unlike most tempura outside of Japan, their tempura batter is light and crisp. Lastly, I was surprised by the atsu age (fried-grilled tofu) - it's simple (just fried tofu in soy sauce) yet you just can't stop eating it for some reason.DON'T GET: Gyu-katsu, it's not bad but also not amazing so I would save your tummy space for something else.OTHER TIPS: Go early or late for the meal to avoid the line, we went at 8:30pm and waited for around 20minutes before we got seated.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Niku Udon (hot)
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Niku Udon (cold)
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Tempura

3NBuK-HMNA64KvZQo33QVw.text: A fine bowl of udon, but not amazing. My recent trip to London saw a rare snowstorm and freezing temperatures, so a large bowl of soup was in the cards. Found this place on Yelp, and my friend and I made our way here at around 9PM on a Saturday night. We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table (5th in line), but the queue quickly grew and was out the door shortly after we were seated.We ordered the pork belly appetizer, niku udon, and duck hotpot udon. The pork belly was tasty, but extremely fatty (50%+ of each piece was pure fat); there wasn't anything really remarkable about it otherwise. The niku udon was much better than the duck, in my opinion, as the rather large chunks of duck meat quickly became chewy as they cooked in the broth, while the thinly sliced beef in the niku was more suited to maintain a tender texture through the meal.The broth of the soups were clean and fresh, not at all too salty or heavy. The noodles however, were a disappointment as they became very soggy/overcooked and started breaking apart in the hot broth. Perhaps the cold dipping noodles are a good way to go to avoid this, but my favorite udon spots in NYC don't have this problem.Bar-only seating, which is cool as you can watch the chefs work.

OfOSZG6P9_KVl--afAFzcA.text: A cozy and quiet Japanese bar located in the bustling heart of Soho. Seating here is limited and most patrons dine alone, especially for breakfast. The menu is mostly comprised of udon dishes, but they also serve rice and other small plates. To help combat the blizzard that's been striking London these days (so unusual!), I ordered a warm bowl of English Breakfast Udon. Kind of overpriced for what you get, but it was pretty good given the dish's simplicity and uniqueness. Only served in the mornings.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. English Breakfast Udon (11.10)

-ik966l91bDuBe7S8hoqdw.text: Stopped in here for dinner one night. The interior is authentic Japanese, dark, cozy, and minimalist with a few tables and open kitchen bar seating. I had the saba/mackerel udon with poached egg added - outstanding! My wife ordered the curry udon and loved it. It was super thick with pudding-like consistency more like a real curry itself and not just curry-spiced normal udon broth. They make the udon noodles in-house, and you can tell. The flavor and texture was better than Shin, the top-rated Udon place in Tokyo.We did some tempura as well, which was outrageously good. This was easily the best shrimp tempura I've ever had even having traveled recently to Japan. We had quick, friendly service throughout the evening. Overall, this was the best meal we had in the UK and made my list of favorite restaurants ever visited from around the world.

kBVpHRul_UeaR37s9BGg9Q.text: My fav udon place in London. Authentic, delicious, healthy, clean and super tasty. I always tend to go for the Niku (hot noodles bowl with beef) dish which is delicious. I love the cute spices pot that they have and I never hesitate to use it. Nothing like a spicy, hot udon pot with some cold sake. The only downside is the seating as there are no tables and you have to sit around the bar. Perfect for two but three are a crowd. It is very popular, there is always a queue but if you go around 9pm it is less busy.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Niku

CMKkF2ODS4BdNhiLuyvWIw.text: We stayed across the street at the historic little hotel, discovered this place by accident. It's cozy, quick seating and the food is mad  fresh at the bar in front of you. I miss this place so much, wish we had one in California. It made me fall in love with udon!If the tempura cabbage is on the menu, order it!! Wow.I recommend all the udon bowls, but especially buta miso and the shrimp tempura.

DoXAIHheyo8uEh-YeMzk6w.text: Small Japanese place with mostly udon menu and some on the rice or other small dishes. My friend had the udon but the portion didn't seem as big compared to other common noodle places you'd see. I had the gyudon and again, smaller portions than other restaurants, but it was still great!

Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Gyudon

Vp4833bpOAhYDANvMiDRWA.text: This time I came food was probably more like a 4.25 but I'm gonna round up to a 5 for old times sake.Just gotta love koya! Always trusty, it never disappoints. Udon is always great. I like kitsune Atsu atsu just because it's classic and you can always count on it being delicious. My boyfriend had the miso pork hiya atsu and that was realllly great too. Prawn Tempura was on point. Came with a good smattering of extra tempura crunch I could just scatter all over my udon. You can tell I was very pleased! I did wish they had a better selection of small plates/ daily specials though, but probably just bad luck on the day I went. Last time I was here they had amazing chicken karaage, so get that if you see it on the specials!

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom. Yum!

3QNLNdPwuT9N2aFSpzjJ0w.text: Intro: I just landed into London, dropped off my bags at my hotel and headed out for lunch solo. My friend told me about Koya and since I love udon I had to try it.  It was later in the afternoon so I was lucky to get a seat right away.Food: I ordered the Buta Udon which was simple, had amazing flavor and was perfect.I also ordered a ride of wings which were ok.  Next time I'm going to try the pork belly.Drinks: I ordered the homemade lemonade which was delicious. Very mild, not tart at all with a hint of honey.Price: £24.05Service:  Very friendlyAmbiance: Its very cozy with just a long bar with the chefs cooking. Probably seats about 20 people. Would I go back? Yes! I love noodles and I want to try all of the udons on the menu!

icQQ6s_zsvTf0UxEw7NWLA.text: Had a nice piping hot bowl of udon to start my snowy day so his made me a happy camper. I got the duck udon which sounded amazing and you definitely can't go wrong with duck. The flavor and texture was good, udon was authentic but wasn't the best I ever had. Good place to eat if you are in the area and craving udon but I wouldn't wait if there was a long wait. Bar seating only so not ideal with a group.

0ALvFcGJQo91nBE037Podg.text: Terrific Udon noodle place in Soho. Reminded me of walk up Udon counters in Tokyo. I got the hot pot Udon which included chicken and vegetables. The broth was on point and the noodles were terrific. Some of the best Udon I've had in years. Great for a cold weather day. Service was quick and efficient. They have a small sake list which is solid.

photos.caption: Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Koya Soho - London, United Kingdom

tvTzftcW5Jet0VkX1wLJsQ.text: The atmosphere is quaint and reminiscent of small Tokyo noodle spots, but the food is pretty awful. We ordered the niku udon and breaded beef small plate. The beef in my udon was served raw which would be fine except the broth was not nearly hot enough to cook the beef through. It was REALLY oily, full of fat, and it cooked to a white color (not brown). It tasted like gelatinous, mushy pork in a kind of herb tinted soup. It was pretty bad. I tried my husband's breaded beef dish and couldn't even bite through it. It was SO chewy... Maybe we came on an off night, but that was probably the worst food I've had in a long time.
